results.title: Speed the scrap [Short version]
results.creator_credit: Frank Green, Ace Films and British Iron and Steel Federation
results.brief_description: Emphasises the fact the Britain is becoming more dependent upon scrap metal to maintain her output of iron and steel. Iron ore deposits in the Midlands and imported ore from Africa provide insufficient supplies for new steel; over half the iron and steel produced in the United Kingdom is made from scrap. shows conversion of scrap to new steel in electric carbon-arc furnaces; by-product of process is slag, used as fertiliser.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Green, Ace Films and British Iron and Steel Federation

results.title: Speed the plough
results.creator_credit: Bob Privett, Allan Crich, British Petroleum and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: An animated film illustrating 600 years of development in agricultural implements from the ox-drawn plough to the mechanised farming equipment of today.

results.title: Speed of sound
results.creator_credit: S.G. Fergusson, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: Simple demonstrations are used to compare the speed of sound through air and through metal. Methods of determing the speed of sound in air, as determined by the French Academy Commission in 1738, and in water, as determined by Colladon and Sturm in Lake Geneva, are illustrated. Practical applications of the speed of sound are mentioned; the use of sound waves in echo sounding and depth plotting; sound ranging in gun location.
results.creator_credit_for_label: S.G. Fergusson, Frank Wells and Gaumont-British Instructional

results.title: Speech skills: using your voice effectively
results.brief_description: In a television setting, pictures projected onto a screen change to live-action examples of situations where the effective use of your voice is important. Problems that are the result of the speaker’s volume, pitch, voice quality and articulation are examined, with suggestions for overcoming them.

results.title: Speech and protest
results.brief_description: Queries the limits to freedom of speech and assembly in America in 1967. After introducing the First Amendment, three enacted sequences are presented: in the first, students in a classroom argue about the government’s foreign policies; in the second, the teacher forcefully leads the discussion, raising the question of academic freedom and the wishes of parents; the third sequence deals with an anti-war demonstration in which a threatening crowd forms, which questions the duty of the police. The film presents conflicting opinions and controversial scenes. It’s purpose: to let you find out what you think. Footage includes demonstrations for civil rights, women’s rights, African-American protest, KKK meetings.

results.title: Spectrum: psychobiology - split brain (D)
results.creator_credit: Jack Willis, Philip Burton, David Prowitt, International Science Magazine and National Educational Television
results.brief_description: This informative piece is based around a doctor who experiments on animals to find out what significance each side of the brain has, thus a monkey is operated on to “split his brain”. Tests are then run to monitor the monkey’s process. Split brain people are then looked into to find out what the left and right side of the brain does. NB: CONTAINS DISTURBING IMAGES OF ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Willis, Philip Burton, David Prowitt, International Science Magazine and National Educational Television

results.title: Spectacular Britain
results.creator_credit: Richard Brock and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: David Attenborough takes the viewer the length of Britain in one year. Some of its most beautiful countryside is shown as well as some fascinating wildlife. The gardens of Buckingham Palace are filmed for the first time.

results.title: Speaking of animals: in South America
results.brief_description: Very humorous North American view of Brazilian/South American jungle life. Great early animation technique. Commentary a bit twee but humorous voice-overs depicting Clark Gable and Ma Kettle give it a great touch. Animation by George Grimshaw. Narration by Ken Carpenter.
